# Who am I? 

::: {.g-col-12}
My name is Bede Ffinian Rowe Davies a Post-Doctoral Researcher in Marine Ecology at **Ifremer** based at the **University of Montpellier**. I am a researcher interested in the large scale changes in marine ecosystems in relation to anthropogenic activities and drivers, using novel techniques alongside traditional methods. 

# Current Post-Doctoral Work

The current project I am taking part in is to use models of Ecosystems to use novels simulation models that effectively couple Physical (Oceanographic), Lower Trophic Level (LTL: Micro-organisms, Phyoplankton and their Elements) and Higher Trophic Level (HTL: Fish, Cephalopods and other large marine organisms). These simulation models are the first to consider the full marine ecosystem as one whole system, interacting dynamically to allow us to test different scenarios of Climate Change and other human impacts, such as Marine Protected Areas and Fisheries, and how these impacts will change under predicted climate change scenarios.

:::

# Previous Post-Doctoral Work

My most recent Post-doctoral work was based at the University of Nantes in France where the project aimed to create scaleable and generaliseable classification models to use **Spectral Reflectance** measured from Satellite imagery to predict spatial extent of intertidal habitats across multiple scales, ranging from the specific sites, to the whole of **Northern Europe** all the way up to **Global** extents. This can assist biodiversity management over great spatial scales while also providing real-time data (assuming regular available satellite imagery). After my PhD I was a Post-Doctoral researcher at the University of Plymouth assessing changes in Blue Carbon stores around Jersey in the UK Channel Islands. The project aimed to assess the stored carbon within sedimentary habitats in Jersey. This information was then being used alongside spatial habitat data to create a preliminary estimate of total carbon within sedimentary habitats across Jersey's territorial waters. Cores and Grabs were taken across Jersey's waters, then prepared and analysed for their total and organic carbon content with CHN analysis.

# PhD 

I completed my PhD based at the University of Plymouth. The title of my PhD was: **The Effectiveness of Partially Protected Marine Areas for Ecosystem Based Fisheries Management.**  The work centred around the Marine Protected Area (**MPA**) in Lyme Bay (UK), which excluded all demersal towed fishing activity across 206km$^2$ of seabed in 2008. University of Plymouth staff and students have monitored the benthic environment across the bay (inside and outside the MPA) annually, using a range of underwater sampling equipment. 

The methods include:

- Passive Acoustic Monitoring (**PAM**)

- Towed Underwater Video Systems (**TUVs**)

- Baited Remote Underwater Video Systems (**BRUVs**) 


![](Images/who/preview-image.png){.preview-image}


The **objective** of my PhD was to assess how the protection affected the benthic ecosystems inside vs outside the MPA. 

::: {.grid}

::: {.g-col-7}

My duties included: 

- the continued application of annual surveys alongside other members of the team,

- organisation of the 12 year data sets for BRUVs and TUVs, and 5 years of PAM recordings,

- analysis of BRUVs and PAM data sets, 

- statistical analysis of the time series data, 

- assessment of the applicability of the methods,

- the creation of journal style articles for publication.
